review.title: Safe Control under Uncertainty
review.abstract: Controller synthesis for hybrid systems that satisfy temporal specifications expressing various system properties is a challenging problem that has drawn the attention of many researchers. However, making the assumption that such temporal properties are deterministic is far from the reality. For example, many of the properties the controller has to satisfy are learned through machine learning techniques based on sensor input data. In this paper, we propose a new logic, Probabilistic Signal Temporal Logic (PrSTL), as an expressive language to define the stochastic properties, and enforce probabilistic guarantees on them. We further show how to synthesize safe controllers using this logic for cyber-physical systems under the assumption that the stochastic properties are based on a set of Gaussian random variables. One of the key distinguishing features of PrSTL is that the encoded logic is adaptive and changes as the system encounters additional data and updates its beliefs about the latent random variables that define the safety properties. We demonstrate our approach by synthesizing safe controllers under the PrSTL specifications for multiple case studies including control of quadrotors and autonomous vehicles in dynamic environments.

sections.heading: 3.2 Controller Synthesis for Signal Temporal Logic
sections.text: Signal-temporal logic (STL) is an expressive framework that makes it possible to think about real-time density-time functions evaluated, and that is widely used to define robustness and monitor the properties of real-time signals of hybrid systems. More recently, there has been interest in synthesizing controllers that meet STL properties [34, 35]. Formally, this means that a signal meets the STL formula "in due time." An atomic predicate of an STL formula is represented by inequalities of form "(t) > 0, where µ is a function of the signal system" in due time. "The truth value of the predicate" µ "(t) > 0. Each STL formula consists of Boolean and temporal operations based on these predicates and the syntax of STL formulas.

sections.heading: 3.3 Bayesian Methods to Model Uncertainty
sections.text: Probability theory provides a natural way to represent environmental uncertainty and recent advances in machine learning and perceptual practice; the two main components comprise (a) Bayean networks (equivalent graphical models), which enable the expression of complex interactions between sets of latent variables, and (b) the Bayean inference procedure, which computes numerically probability distributions across variables of interest. One of the key aspects of Bayean methodology is that, unlike other optimization methods, the entire distributions are available across the variables of interest. Such distributions characterize the uncertainty in the system and are critical to our goal of synthesizing secure controllers. While a thorough discussion of Bayesian networks and associated methods of modelling uncertainty goes beyond the scope of this paper, we emphasize these methods on the task of classification.

sections.heading: 4. PROBLEM STATEMENT
sections.text: The key idea of our work is to first integrate random variables into predicates and then express temporal and Boolean operations on such predicates. The proposed logic provides a meaningful framework for defining security conditions under a variety of uncertainties, including the uncertainty created by the use of classifiers for machine learning. At the core of this work is the recognition that when uncertainty about the random variable is established in a Bayesian framework, we can use the probability distributions derived from it to efficiently derive constraints from the PrSTL specifications. We offer a novel solution for synthesizing controllers for dynamic systems with different PrSTL characteristics. An interesting aspect of this framework is that the PrSTL formulas can evolve at each step.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Key contributions include the definition of PrSTL, a logic for expressing probabilistic properties that enables the embedding of Bayesian graphical models. We also show how the control can be synthesized in a retreating horizontal frame under PrSTL specifications that express Bayesian linear classifiers. Another characteristic aspect of this work is that the resulting logic adapts as more data is observed with the evolution of the system. We show the effectiveness of the approach by synthesizing secure strategies for a quadrotor and an autonomous vehicle that moves in uncertain environments. The approach presented easily extends to distributions other than Gauss on Bayesian approximation techniques [28, 4] that can project distributions onto Gaussian densities.
